(2) Subsection (1) shall not apply to a fundraising for a person who is contesting an election under this Act or to a fundraising for a political party.'); (E6-18(1) -'(1) The persons who nominate a presidential candidate shall be members of the candidate’s political party.'); (E6-18(2) - '(1) A person qualifies to be nominated by a political party for presidential elections if that person, (a) is selected in the manner provided for in the constitution or rules of the political party concerned relating to members of that party who wish to contest presidential elections, and (b) subject to subsection (4) (according to which - 'the authorised person or persons as per subsection (3) [subsection (3) - 'every political party shall notify the Commission of the name of the person(s) authorised by the party to certify to the Commission that a person has or persons have been selected by the party + the person(s) so named must deposit their specimen signature with the Commission in such a manner as the Commission may require'] shall, in writing, certify that a candidate has been nominated by the party'), the party certifies the nomination to the Commission. (2) Every political party shall submit the names of the party candidates who have been selected to participate in the general elections under this Act at least sixty days before the elections, (2A) A political party shall, at least twenty-one days before the nomination day, submit to the Commission the names of the persons contesting in its party primary and the date of its party primary. (2B) A candidate for a presidential, election shall be selected by persons who are members of the respective political parties and whose names appear on the party membership list as submitted to the Commission.'); (page E6-24 - '(1) A public officer who intends to contest an election under this Act shall resign from public office at least six months before the date of election. (1A) A public officer who intends to contest in a by-election under this Act shall resign from public office within seven days of the declaration of a vacancy. (2) This section shall not apply to, (a) the President, (c) the Deputy President, (d) a member of Parliament, (e) a county governor, (f) a deputy county governor, (g) a member of a county assembly.');} {(Elections Regulations, Page - '(1)' [as above - B35]);} {(PP & PLists Regulatiosn, Page 323-324 - '(1) The conduct of party primaries [process of selecting candidates for election - doesn't include party lists] and party nomination of party lists [the process through which a political party elects or selects its candidates for party lists] shall, (a) be democratic, free and fair, (b) provide equal opportunities for all eligible candidates, (c) not discriminate against any eligible candidate, (d) be inclusive and participatory, (e) be open, transparent and accountable, (f) be credible, and (g) be peaceful. (2) Every political party shall, upon submission of their nomination rules and procedures to the Commission pursuant to section 27 of the Act (a) make them available and accessible to the members of the party with specific considerations to members with disabilities, (b) place a copy at the party’s head office and branch offices, (c) post them on the party’s website. (3) Where the Commission determines that the party nomination rules and procedures do not conform to the requirements of the constitution of the political party, the Act and these Regulations, the Commission may require the political party to review and amend the party nomination rules and procedures so that they conform to the constitution of the political party, the Act and these Regulations. (4) Every political party shall prepare and communicate to its members a party nomination code of conduct at least thirty days before the conduct of party primaries or nomination of the party list, whichever is the earlier. (5) Every political party shall require an aspiring candidate to sign and ascribe to the party’s nomination code of conduct set out in Form 1 [see page 331] of the Schedule.'); (Page 324-325 - '(1) Every political party shall appoint a national Election Board and may appoint county Election Boards in respect of every county where the party is offering candidates for election. (2) An Election Board shall comprise of not more than seven and not less than three members including one person to represent special interest groups, (3) An Election Board shall be responsible for conducting or supervising party primaries and party nomination of party lists and any other related activities for purposes of selection of candidates to participate in an election. (4) The Election Board shall notify members of the party of the date by which applications must be received, the date, time and venue of the party primary, (5) The nomination officials appointed by an Election Board shall conduct the party primary, tally the votes and present the results to an Election Board. (6) An Election Board shall declare the results in Form 2 [see page 331-332] set out in the Schedule and shall require the aspiring candidates or their agents to be present to sign the Form as acceptance of the process and the result.'); (page 326 - '(1) Every political party may, at least two weeks before a party primary or nomination of the party lists, announce the fees to be levied by the party on every aspiring candidate. (2) An aspiring candidate shall submit to an Election Board of their party, a duly filled application in Form 3 [see page 333-334] set out in the Schedule together with, (a) a signed commitment to the political party’s constitution, policies and principles, (b) a self-declaration form as prescribed under the Leadership and Integrity Act, 2012, (c) copies of the person’s national identity card or valid passport, (d) copies of the candidate’s academic qualifications from the relevant institutions, (e) evidence of registration as a member of the party, and (f) a receipt or other evidence of payment of nomination fees. (3) Where an aspiring candidate intends to be nominated on the ground that the candidate is a person with disability, the candidate shall also submit an application in Form 4 [see page 334] set out in the Schedule which shall be certified by the National Council for Persons with Disabilities. (4) A party primary shall be conducted in accordance with the nomination rules and procedures of the party, (4A) the candidate who obtains the highest number of votes shall be declared the party nominee for the position. (4B) Where only one aspiring candidate applies to be nominated in any elective position, no party primary shall be conducted, (5) An Election Board shall in writing certify and declare the aspiring candidate as the party nominee, (6) Upon conclusion of the party primary, the authorized party officials shall certify the list of nominees and submit it to the Commission, (7) Upon receipt of the list by the Commission, the list shall not be altered.'); (page 327 - '(1) Where the political party is required to issue a notice to its members regarding any exercise in the conduct of a party primary the party shall, (a) notify its members at least seven days before the date of the exercise, and (b) publish the notice in its website. (2) Every political party shall, at the time of submission of nominees to the Commission, file a statutory declaration signed by the person authorized to certify that candidate, to the effect that the political party has complied with the nomination rules and procedures of the party in the conduct of the party primary. (2A) The statutory declaration shall be in Form 5 [see page 334-335] set out in the Schedule. (2B) An aspiring candidate in a party primary may appoint an agent to represent his or her interests during the exercise. (2C) An agent shall be appointed in writing by the candidate and shall (a) be a registered member of the political party, (b) be issued with an appointment letter by the aspiring candidate identifying him or her as the agent of that candidate; and (c) have access to information relating to the party primary.'); (page 328-329 - '(1) A political party that requests the Commission to supervise its party primary - in accordance with Article 88 of the constitution - shall be responsible for the preparatory work, (2) The Commission’s role in party primary shall be limited to the supervision, conduct, announcement and declaration of the results of the party primary on the day set aside for the primary and shall not participate in the preparation of party lists save as authorised under the law. (3) A party primary conducted and supervised by the Commission shall be, (a) through a secret ballot; and (b) determined by a majority of valid votes cast by the eligible voters. (4) The Commission shall publicly announce and declare the candidate who has obtained the highest number of valid votes to be duly nominated and shall issue a certificate to the duly nominated candidate. (5) In the event of a tie among the top candidates, the Commission shall hold a fresh party primary and the candidates in that party primary shall be only the candidates who garnered the highest number of votes. (6)  the Commission shall submit the results of the party primary to the Election Board of the party, (6A) The Election Board shall certify the list of nominees and the party authorized official shall formally submit the list to the Commission.'); (page 330 - '(1) The Commission shall reject a list or a name on the list of nominees submitted by a political party where (a) the list does not conform to the requirements of the Constitution, the Act or these Regulations, or (b) the period for submitting a revised list/nominee has lapsed. (2) Where the Commission rejects a party's list or a nominee on the list, it shall require the political party to resubmit the list or nominee within such period as the Commission may specify. (2A) A political party resubmitting a list/nominee shall resubmit the declaration under Regulation 18 [see page 327 above] to the effect that the political party has complied with the nomination rules and procedures of the party relating to the nomination of the names contained in the list/nominees. (2B) In the event that a political party fails to resubmit the list or a name on the party list after it has been rejected, the party shall not be considered in the ballot.'); (page 330 - '(1) Every political party shall establish an internal dispute resolution mechanism in relation to the party primaries. (1A) The dispute resolution mechanism of a party shall be independent of the party leadership and other party institutions. (1B) The dispute resolution mechanism of a party shall hear and determine all nomination disputes not later than ninety days before the date of general election. (2) The contravention of any of the provisions of the Election Offences Act (2016) or the breach of the Electoral Code of Conduct shall constitute electoral malpractice in relation to a party primary and party nomination of party lists.')
BPRESSELTXT: {(ODM Election & Nomination Rules, page 6 - (1) 'The NEB may with the written approval of the National Executive Committee (NEC) grant a candidate an automatic nomination, (2) Duties of the National Elections Board shall include the vetting of all candidates aspiring for nomination on the party ticket'); (page 22 - (1) 'Upon a resolution by the NEC, the NEB shall advertise and receive applications in forms prescribed for nominations for the position of President, (2) The NEB shall establish candidates vetting committees, subject to approval of the NEC and which shall be responsible for vetting of candidates,'); (page 27-28 - '(1) A person seeking nomination for Presidential elections shall fulfill the following requirements: i. Be a Kenyan citizen with a National Identity Card or passport, ii. Be 35 years of age and above, iii. Be a registered voter, iv. Be a life member of the Party, v. Is a holder of a degree from a university recognized in Kenya, vi. Be of high moral standing and integrity, vii. Meet the minimum requirements for Presidential Candidates as set out by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission of Kenya, or viii. Is qualified to stand for election as a Member of Parliament. (2) Candidates in respect of Presidential nomination shall be required to provide the following: i. Duly completed Nomination Form in duplicate, ii. Copy of national identity card or Passport, iii. A copy of Elector’s card, iv. A copy of Orange Democratic Movement Life Membership Certificate, v. A non- refundable fee as shall be determined from time to time by the National Executive Committee on recommendation of the National Elections Board paid to Orange Democratic Movement by a Bankers Cheque or deposited in the Party account, vi. A copy of the degree certificate obtained from a university recognized in Kenya, vii. Duly executed Code of Conduct and Pledge of Commitment Form, viii. (evidence that they) Meet all other requirements under the Elections Act and Regulations made by the Commission.'); (page 28-31 - '(1) (Only) where more than one candidate qualifies for nomination, there shall be an election to nominate the Party’s Presidential candidate, (2) The Members of the National Delegates Convention shall convert into a National Electoral College and nominate the Presidential Candidate, (3) The date of the National Delegates Convention shall be announced by the National Executive Committee, (4) Voting shall be by secret ballot. (5) eligible voters shall be identified through the following documents: a. Orange Democratic Movement membership card, b. National Identity card or Passport, c. Voters’ card and d. National Electoral College Voters Register. (6) Each Presidential Candidate shall be entitled to appoint Agents as shall be determined by the NEB. (7)  The NEB shall present the results of the Presidential nominations to the National Delegates Convention. (8) If only one candidate presents him/herself for nomination, the NEB shall present the said candidate to the National Delegates Convention for endorsement. (9) where no appeal has been lodged at the National Elections Appeals Tribunal, the NEB shall proceed to process and issue the nomination certificate to the declared winner within seven (7) days of the primaries or determination of a dispute. (10) The NEB shall accordingly enter the name of the winner on the Party list and the same shall not be removed except by a decision of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission, Complaints and Dispute Resolution Committee or an order of the High Court.'); (page 32-34 - '(1) The National Appeals Tribunal shall determine appeals arising from nominations in respect of Presidential elections, (2) appeals to the National Appeals Tribunal shall be in writing duly signed by the appellant and shall be lodged within 48 hours of the announcement of results appealed from, (3) An appellant shall, on appeal, pay a non-refundable fee of Ksh. 70,000/= to the Party. (4) The National Appeals Tribunal shall, in suitable cases, and with relevant evidence, have powers to dismiss the appeal or order re-count, re-tallying of votes or repeat of elections, (5) The National Appeals Tribunal shall consider and determine the appeal in accordance with the Constitution of Kenya, any applicable Law, Party Constitution and Election and Nomination Rules within 48 hours of receipt of the appeal. (5A) The decision of the National Appeals Tribunal shall be final. (6) All applicants for nomination as party candidates shall sign a Code of Conduct, Pledge of Commitment to make monthly contributions towards the financing of Party operations and a pledge to the party manifesto which Pledge shall be witnessed by a Commissioner of Oaths or Magistrate, (6A) The amounts to be pledged by Party candidates shall be set out and reviewed from time to time by the NEC, (6B) The amounts pledged shall be recoverable by the Party as a civil debt.'); (page 35-37 - 'Grounds for disqualification as a candidate for any nomination: A member shall be disqualified to be a candidate for any nomination if: a. Without authority he makes, prepares, prints or is in possession of a document or paper purporting to be a register of Party members, b. knowingly makes any false statement on, or in connection with any application to be registered in any register of Party members, c. acts corruptly, for the purpose of influencing a voter to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate before or during an election, d. is involved in bribery directly or indirectly by making any gift, loan, offer, promise, procurement, or agreement to any election official or voter to, i. Procure the election or nomination of any person, or ii. Procure the vote of any voter at any election or nomination; Grounds for disqualification from voting as a member/delegate: A Party member shall be disqualified to vote at an election for the nomination of any candidate if he or she a. induces, influences or procures any other person to vote in an election knowing that the person is not entitled to vote in that election, b. accepts or takes any provision knowing that it is intended to influence them, c. directly or indirectly in person or through another person on his behalf uses or threatens to use any force, violence or any fraudulent device, trick or deception for the purpose of or on account of i. inducing or compelling a person to vote or not to vote for a particular candidate at an election for nomination, ii. Impeding or preventing the free exercise of the franchise of a voter, iii. Inducing or compelling a person to refrain from becoming a candidate or to withdraw if he has become a candidate, iv. Impeding or preventing a person from being nominated as a candidate or from being registered as a voter. d. indirectly by duress or intimidation i. Impedes, prevents or threatens to impede or prevent a voter from voting, ii. in any manner influences the result of an election.'); (page 38 - '(1) The NEB shall compile and certify the list of all successful candidates, (2) Upon receipt of a certified list of the candidates, the authorized Party signatories shall issue a Nomination Certificate and forward to the Commission the Party List in accordance with Sec. 35 of the Elections Act, 2011.');} {(Page 33 Party statute - NEC to make Elections and Nomination Rules and/or Regulations as may be prescribed under this Constitution and lay them before the National Governing Council (+NDC) for ratification.)}
C46PLSELTXT: (ODM Nomination & Election Rules, page 6 - (1) 'The NEB may with the written approval of the National Executive Committee (NEC) grant a candidate an automatic nomination, (2) Duties of the National Elections Board shall include the vetting of all candidates aspiring for Party election') (page 11-12 - '(1) A candidate seeking to be elected in office shall: a. Be a member of the Orange Democratic Movement, b. Be committed to ideals and core values of the Party, c. Be a fully paid up member; in the case of those seeking for national office be life members, d. Demonstrate having participated in party activities for at least one year prior to his/her application for election, e. Complete and return within the time stipulated by the NEB Party election nomination form prescribed in Schedule II to these rules [NB not there] and the Party Code of Conduct, f. Be a delegate by virtue of having been elected from the Grassroots [i.e., be a national official], g. Be an automatic delegate by virtue of having been elected as ODM Members of Parliament or Governors. h. Be present during the meeting at which the election is conducted, (2) The National officials shall be elected by the National Delegates Convention (NDC) convened in accordance with provisions of the Party Constitution, (3) The NEB shall ensure that only the delegates whose names appear in the National Delegates Register and present at the Convention shall be eligible to vote, (4) There must be a quorum of 30% of eligible voting delegates [see Statute page 30], (4) Elections at the National Delegates Convention shall be by secret ballot or any other method approved by the delegates in session, (5) Persons elected to national offices shall upon declaration of results of election assume office with immediate effect.') (page 22 - (1) 'Upon a resolution by the NEC, the NEB shall advertise and receive applications in forms prescribed, (2) The NEB shall establish candidates vetting committees, subject to approval of the NEC and which shall be responsible for vetting of candidates,') (page 32-33 - '(1) The National Appeals Tribunal shall determine appeals arising from elections of National officials, (2) appeals to the National Appeals Tribunal shall be in writing duly signed by the appellant and shall be lodged within 48 hours of the announcement of results appealed from, (3) an appellant shall, on appeal, pay a non-refundable fee of Ksh. 70,000/= to the Party, (4) The National Appeals Tribunal shall, in suitable cases, have powers to dismiss the appeal or order re-count, re-tallying of votes or repeat of elections, (5) The National Appeals Tribunal shall consider and determine the appeal in accordance with the Constitution of Kenya, any applicable Law, Party Constitution and Election and Nomination Rules within 48 hours of receipt of the appeal, (6) The decision of the National Appeals Tribunal shall be final,') (page 35 - '(1)  Where an office is contested by more than one candidate, the vote shall be decided by a simple majority, (2) Where only one candidate is nominated to an office at the close of the nominations, that candidate shall be declared duly elected to the office for which he/she was nominated, (3) Nominations of all candidates shall be in the prescribed form') (page 35-37 - Grounds for disqualification as a candidate: A member shall be disqualified to be a candidate for any nomination if: a. Without authority he makes, prepares, prints or is in possession of a document or paper purporting to be a register of Party members, b. knowingly makes any false statement on, or in connection with any application to be registered in any register of Party members, c. acts corruptly, for the purpose of influencing a voter to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate before or during an election, d. is involved in bribery directly or indirectly by making any gift, loan, offer, promise, procurement, or agreement to any election official or voter to, i. Procure the election or nomination of any person, or ii. Procure the vote of any voter at any election or nomination; Grounds for disqualification from voting as a member/delegate: A Party member shall be disqualified to vote at an election for the nomination of any candidate if he or she a. induces, influences or procures any other person to vote in an election knowing that the person is not entitled to vote in that election, b. accepts or takes any provision knowing that it is intended to influence them, c. directly or indirectly in person or through another person on his behalf uses or threatens to use any force, violence or any fraudulent device, trick or deception for the purpose of or on account of i. inducing or compelling a person to vote or not to vote for a particular candidate at an election for nomination, ii. Impeding or preventing the free exercise of the franchise of a voter, iii. Inducing or compelling a person to refrain from becoming a candidate or to withdraw if he has become a candidate, iv. Impeding or preventing a person from being nominated as a candidate or from being registered as a voter. d. indirectly by duress or intimidation i. Impedes, prevents or threatens to impede or prevent a voter from voting, ii. in any manner influences the result of an election.')}; {(Party Statute, page14 - '(1) Election of National Officials shall be conducted on the guiding principle that at least one third shall be of either gender, (2) All National Officials other than the Secretary for Parliamentary Affairs, Secretary for Women Affairs, Secretary for Youth Affairs, and the Executive Director shall be elected by the National Delegates Conference [also see page 28; also NGC can constitutionally make nomination on behalf of NDC see C43APLSELC]. (2A) The Party Leader shall remain in office until the next election of National Officials. (2B) In the event that the Party Leader is unable to discharge of his or her duties by reason of physical or mental infirmity, death, resignation or where he or she ceases to be a Party member or a Member of Parliament, a Special Session of the National Delegates Conference shall be convened to elect a new Party Leader. (3) Elections shall be through secret ballot or any other method of voting acceptable to the delegates in session [page 30 - other methods are 'vote by consensus, secret ballot or by a unanimous resolution], (4) where an office is contested by more than one candidate, the vote shall be decided by a simple majority, (5) Where only one candidate is nominated to an office at the close of the nominations, that candidate shall be declared duly elected to the office for which he/she was nominated, (6) Nomination to the Office of Party Leader shall be by a written application to the National Elections Board in the prescribed form') (Page 52 - '(1) All Party Officials shall not hold more than one office in the Party. (2) Any vacancy occurring in the Party organs during the course of the term before the next National Delegates Conference or Party Election as the case may be, shall be filled in acting capacity ,through nomination by the National Executive Committee upon recommendations of the relevant Party organ until the vacancy is substantially filled. (3) The National Executive Committee shall have the power to make rules for the better carrying out of all matters provided in this Constitution. Such Rules shall be consistent with provisions of this Constitution and, where inconsistent, such rules made shall be void to the extent of the inconsistency thereof.')}
C62ELTITLE: Presidential nominee (or 'President' if party wins election)/ Leader of the Opposition (if party doesn't win election)/ 'flag bearer'

TITLE: Political Party Database
A4RECPARTYTXT: To register as a political party in Kenya there is a two step process, provisional then full registration. In the first step, Kenyan parties must register provisionally with the Registrar of Political Parties, which involves submitting a provisional application (in writing and signed by the applicants, of whom not more than two-thirds shall be of the same gender). This is to be accompanied by: a) signed minutes of the first meeting of the founding members of the party, b) suggested party name, c) abbreviation of name of party (if party wants one), d) copy of the party's Constitution (must comply with the provisions of section 9 and the Second Schedule of the Political Parties Act), e) an undertaking to be bound by the Political Parties Act and the Code of Conduct set out in the First Schedule (P19-27), f) prescribed registration fee (100,000ksh + 500ksh for 'name search' - checks no other parties already registered under name), g) a request for the registration of the symbol of the political party. NOTE: Registrar will within 14 days, publish a notice in the Government Gazette and in at least two newspapers with nationwide circulation, inviting objections from any person or any other political party concerning the registration of the name, symbol, colour of the political party, or any other issue relating to the registration of the political party. After verification by Registrar that the party's application for registration is complete, they will issue a certificate of provisional registration within 30 days of receipt of application. However, provisional registration does not entitle a party to participate in an election, it must be fully registered. In the second step, (AND within 180-days of receipt of certificate of provisional registration), these parties can apply for full registration with the Registrar by submitting an application for full registration (in writing and signed by the authorized official(s) of the party). A political party is qualified for full registration if, a) it has recruited as members, not fewer than 1000 registered voters in each of more than half of the counties; b) the members reflect regional and ethnic diversity, gender balance and representation of special interest groups; c) the composition of its governing body reflects regional and ethnic diversity, gender balance and representation of special interest groups; d) not more than two-thirds of the members of its governing body are of the same gender; e) it has demonstrated (with proof) that members of its governing body meet the requirements of Chapter Six of the Constitution and the laws relating to ethics (section 7(3) of the Political Parties Act); f) it has undertaken to be bound by the Political Parties Act and the Code of Conduct set out in the First Schedule of the Act; g) paid the prescribed fee (500,000ksh); h) it has submitted to the Registrar: 1) a list of the names, addresses and identification particulars of all its members;  2) tangible proof, such as lease agreement, of the location of its head office, which shall be a registered office within Kenya and a postal address to which notices and other communication may be sent; 3) the location and addresses of the branch offices of the political party, which shall be in more than half of the counties; 4) (proof of b) the disaggregated data of its membership based on each of the components of the special interest groups (special interest groups: women, persons with disabilities, youth, ethnic minorities and marginalized communities); 5) a list of members of its governing body and proof that this body reflects c) and d) above; 6) extracts of voters' register in respect to the more than 1000 members from each of more than a half the counties (including authorised officials/office bearers and members of executive committee and other organs). The extract must be certified by a relevant official from the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission; 7) an affidavit from the Secretary General of the party (duly sworn before a Magistrate/Commissioner for Oaths, or Commissioner/Notary Public) affirming that no member of the party is a member of any other political party already registered with the Registrar and that the member was recruited using established procedures; 8) proof of payment/cheque of prescribed amount

B2BALLOTTXT: {(Party must be registered with the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC - hereafter 'the Commission) to be able to participate in any election' (see A4RECPARTYTXT);} {(Elections Act, Page E6-13 - "(1) A political party shall nominate its candidates for an election under this Act at least ninety days before a general election in accordance with its constitution and nomination rules. (2) A political party shall not change the candidate nominated after the nomination of that person has been received by the Commission: Provided that in the event of the death, resignation or incapacity of the nominated candidate or of the violation of the electoral code of conduct by the nominated candidate, the political party may after notifying the candidate that the party seeks to substitute, where applicable, substitute its candidate before the date of presentation of nomination papers to the Commission. (2A) A political party shall hear and determine all intra party disputes arising from political party nominations within thirty days. (3) Notwithstanding subsection (1), in the case of any other election, the Commission shall by notice in the prescribed form, specify the day or days upon which political parties shall nominate candidates to contest in a presidential, parliamentary or county election in accordance with its constitution or rules, which shall be at least fifty-five days before such election); (E6-18(1) - "(1) A political party shall submit its nomination rules to the Commission at least six months before the nomination of its candidates. (2A) Upon receipt of the nomination rules from a political party the Commission shall, within fourteen days, review the rules to ensure compliance with the prescribed regulations and, (a) issue the political party with a certificate of compliance, or (b) require the political party to amend the rules to ensure such compliance within fourteen days. (2B) For purposes of (2A), the Commission shall, by notice in the Gazette, issue Regulations prescribing guidelines to be complied with and the process by which political parties nominate candidates for nomination in accordance with Article 88 (4) (d) of the Constitution.... (1) A political party that nominates a person for an election under this Act shall submit to the Commission a membership list of the party, (a) in the case of a general election, at least one hundred and twenty days before the date of the election; and (b) in the case of a by-election, forty-five days before the date of the by-election.; (E6-18(2) - '(1) A person qualifies to be nominated by a political party for parliamentary elections for the purposes of Articles 97 of the Constitution if that person- (a) is selected in the manner provided for in the constitution or rules of the political party concerned relating to members of that party who wish to contest parliamentary elections; and (b) subject to subsection (4) (according to which - 'the authorised person or persons as per subsection (3) [subsection (3) - 'every political party shall notify the Commission of the name of the person(s) authorised by the party to certify to the Commission that a person has or persons have been selected by the party + the person(s) so named must deposit their specimen signature with the Commission in such a manner as the Commission may require'] shall, in writing, certify that a candidate has been nominated by the party'), the party certifies the nomination to the Commission. (2A) Every political party shall submit the names of the party candidates who have been selected to participate (directly - Article 97(1)(a & b)) in the general elections under this Act at least sixty days before the elections. (2B) A political party shall, at least twenty-one days before the nomination day, submit to the Commission the names of the persons contesting in its party primary and the date of its party primary.'); (E6-19 - '(1) A political party which nominates a candidate for election under Article 97(1)(a) and (b) shall submit to the Commission a party list - in order of priority - in accordance with Article 97(1)(c) of the Constitution [i.e., for the 12 available positions in the National Assembly that are allocated proportionally]'); (E6-20 - '(1) The party lists submitted to the Commission shall be in accordance with the constitution or nomination rules of the political party concerned. (1A) The Commission shall review the list to ensure compliance with the prescribed regulations and, (a) issue the political party with a certificate of compliance; or (b) require the political party to amend the party list to ensure such compliance failing which the Commission shall reject the list. (1B) For purposes of subsection (1A), the Commission may, by notice in the gazette, issue regulations prescribing guidelines to be complied with in preparation of party lists. (2) A person who is nominated by a political party under Article 97(1)(c) of the Constitution shall be a person who is a member of the political party on the date of submission of the party list by the political party. (3) The party list shall not contain a name of a candidate nominated (directly - Article 97(1)(a & b)) for an election. (10) A party list submitted for purposes of Atricle 97(1)(c) shall not be amended during the term of Parliament for which the candidates are selected. (11) A political party shall submit its party list to the Commission at least forty-five days before the date of the general election [NB party list is different to list of candidates selected to participate in the general elections DIRECTLY discussed earlier]. (12) party list submitted by a political party under Article 97(1)(c) of the Constitution shall include twelve candidates.); (E6-21 - '(1) where a party list is required [i.e., for the 12 available positions in the National Assembly that are allocated proportionally],'a party list submitted shall contain alternates between male and female candidates in the priority in which they are listed'. '(1) If a representative from a political party list dies, withdraws from the party list, changes parties, resigns or is expelled from his or her party during the term of the representative, the seat of the representative shall be allocated to the next candidate of the same gender on the respective political party list. (2) if there are no more candidates on the same party’s list, the Commission shall require the concerned political party to nominate another candidate within twenty-one days. (4) Where a political party fails to comply with the provisions of (2) the Commission shall not allocate the seat for the remainder of the term of Parliament or the county assembly.'); (E6-42 - '(1) Every political party and every person who participates in an election under the Constitution and this Act shall subscribe to and observe the Electoral Code of Conduct set out in the Second Schedule of the Elections Act [2011 - see E6-45-E6-52]. (2) A political party that is eligible to nominate candidates under the Constitution, this Act or any other written law shall not be eligible to contest in any election unless the political party and the candidate have subscribed to the Electoral Code of Conduct');} {(Elections Regulations, Page 91 - ' (1) A political party that intends to nominate a candidate for an elective post under the Elections Act (hereafter 'the Act') shall observe the provisions of the Constitution, the Act and any other written law in respect of the qualifications and disqualifications for that office. (1A) A political party whose nomination rules have been declared void by the Commission under section 27(2B) of the Act shall not participate in the elections. (2) The Commission shall reject a candidate submitted by a political party for any elective post if the candidate is not qualified or eligible for election under the Constitution, the Act or any other written law. (3) Each political party shall issue a nomination certificate, duly signed by the authorized party officials, to the candidate nominated to participate in the elections. (4) The Commission shall reject a nomination certificate which has any alterations. (5) Each political party shall submit to the Commission a party membership list as prescribed in Form 11A (see page 121). (5A) Each political party shall submit only the name of one person as their candidate for any electoral area as defined in the Act. (6) Each political party shall submit to the Commission the date, venue and names of persons contesting in party primaries in both printed and electronic format set out in Forms 11D & 11E (see page 122-123). (7) Every political party shall submit the names the party candidates who have been selected to participate in the general elections in both printed and electronic format as prescribed in Forms 11J & 11K (see page 125). (8) Each political party intending to present a candidate in an election shall, after its nominations and on such date or within such period as the Commission may designate, submit a list of persons nominated as (direct) candidates indicating the elective posts to which they are seeking election. (8A) The list submitted shall be signed by the authorised official of the political party.'); (Page 93 - '(1) A political party candidate at a parliamentary election for the National Assembly or county woman representative shall be nominated by a political party by delivery, to the returning officer on the day fixed for the nomination of candidates at that election, of an application for nomination in Form 15 & 15A for woman representative' (see page 130-132).); (Page 94  - '(1) An application for nomination for candidature at a parliamentary election shall be accompanied by a non-refundable nomination fee, in banker’s draft, of (a) ten thousand shillings for a candidate who is a youth, woman or person with disability; and (b) twenty thousand shillings for any other candidate.'); (Page 96 - '(1) A nomination paper submitted by a political party candidate to the Commission shall (a) contain the candidate’s name as it appears in the register of voters, (b) be signed by the candidate and by a proposer and seconder who shall be voters registered in the respective electoral areas, and who shall be members of the political party, and by an authorised official of the political party; and (c) be delivered to the returning officer personally by the candidate or by a person authorised by the candidate in that behalf on the day set for the nomination. (2) A person nominated to contest in a parliamentary or county election shall submit to the returning officer together with the application for nomination a statutory declaration in Form 19 (see page 136). (3) Where a candidate has applied for nomination in accordance with these Regulations, unless the returning officer holds a nomination paper invalid in accordance with these Regulations [see page 96-97 for reasons that nomination paper may be considered invalid], or the candidate withdraws his or her candidature, or proof is given to the satisfaction of the returning officer of the candidates’ death, the candidate named therein shall stand validly nominated = ballot access.'); (Page 97 - '(1) A candidate whose nomination papers have been delivered to the returning officer may, before the close of nominations, by notice in writing signed by him or her before the returning officer and presented to the returning officer, withdraw his or her candidature.(2) No person shall be a subscriber (proposer or seconder - see above) to more than one nomination paper in respect of different candidates in the same election and if any person subscribes to more than one nomination paper such subscription shall be inoperative (void) on nomination papers (unless this is caused by the candidate they previously subecribed, dying or withdrawing from election). (3) A candidate shall obtain and submit a self-declaration form (ethical requirements) as prescribed under the Leadership and Integrity Act, 2012 (No. 19 of 2012).'); (Page 98 - ' (1) a person seeking nomination shall submit to the Commission certified copies of certificates of their educational qualification. (1A) Where the body that issued the certificate is not based in Kenya, a candidate shall be required to seek authentication of that body with the Kenya National Examinations Council, in the case of form four certificates, or the Commission for University Education, in the case of university degrees. (2) No person shall be entitled to attend the proceedings taking place during the time fixed for the delivery of nomination papers unless that person is, (a) a candidate, (b) a person nominated as deputy to the candidate, where applicable, (c) an agent, or, (d) present for the purpose of assisting the returning officer at the request of the returning officer, (2A) Only two persons shall be entitled to attend these proceedings at any one time, in respect of any one candidate, whether one of the two persons is the candidate himself or herself or not, (3) A person entitled to attend these proceedings shall also be entitled to inspect and to object to the validity of any nomination paper delivered in his or her presence'); (Page 99 - '(1) A candidate who has been nominated may withdraw his or her candidature by delivering to the respective returning officer a notice to that effect in Form 24A [see page 139-140] not later than three days after nomination'); (Page 100 - '(1) Each political party shall submit to the Commission a party list of all persons who would stand elected if the party were entitled to seats in the National Assembly on the basis of proportional representation in accordance with Article 90 of the Constitution [i.e., the 12 aforementioned seats in the National Assembly]. (1A) The party list referred to shall contain the name, address, age, sex, disability and category of disability, phone number, occupation, identity card number or passport number and colored passport size photograph image, elective post sought and such other qualifications as are provided under the Constitution and the Act in the prescribed Form 24B [see page 140]. (1B)  The party list submitted shall be in accordance with section 36 of the Act, and shall be (a) signed by the authorised official of the political party submitting the party list, and (b) be submitted in hard copy, in electronic form and such other form that the Commission may specify. (2) Each political party list nominee shall after nomination, submit to the Commission a letter stating his or her intention to serve if nominated. (2A) Each political party list nominee representing persons with disabilities shall submit, to the Commission, a certification from the National Council for Persons with Disabilities. (3) The Commission may reject a nominee submitted by a political party for any elective post if that nominee is not qualified to be elected to the office for which the nomination is sought as specified under the Constitution or the Act. (3A) The Commission, after making the decision to reject a nominee, inform the political party concerned of that decision and request that political party to submit another name within such time as the Commission shall determine. (4) The party list  shall be prepared in accordance with the nomination rules of the political party. (4A) The Commission shall within fourteen days of receipt reject any party list that does not comply with the requirements of the Constitution, the Act or these Regulations. (4B) The political party whose party list or nominee (on list) has been rejected by the Commission shall resubmit the party list or nominee within seven days from the date that the party list or nominee was rejected. (4C) Where a political party fails to amend the party list or resubmit the list as directed by the Commission, the Commission shall reject the party list. (4D) A political party submitting a party list shall submit a declaration to the effect that the political party has complied with its rules relating to the nomination of the names contained in the list.') (Page 101 - '(1) Every political party shall at least fourteen days to the date of the election submit to the Commission the names of one national chief elections agent and forty-seven county chief elections agents.') (Page 116 - '(1) Where in these Regulations expression is used requiring, authorizing, or implying that, any act is to be done in the presence of the candidates or agents, that expression shall be regarded as reference to the presence of such candidates or agents as may be required or authorized to attend. (1A) The mere non-attendance of any candidate or agents at the time and place as contemplated under subregulation (1) shall not, if any act is otherwise lawfully done, invalidate that act.');} {(PP & PLists Regulations, Page - '(1)' [see below - B3])}
B3CANLAW1TXT: {(Elections Act, Page E6 - 16 - "A person may be nominated as a candidate for an election under this Act only if that person, (a) is qualified to be elected to that office under the Constitution and this Act, and (b) holds in the case of a Member of Parliament, a degree from a university recognized in Kenya"..... "this section shall come into force and shall apply to qualifications for candidates in the general elections to be held after the 2017 general elections."); (E6-17 - "A person qualifies for nomination as a member of Parliament if the person (is nominated by a political party and), (a) is registered as a voter; (b) satisfies any educational, moral and ethical requirements prescribed by the Constitution and the Elections Act...... A person is disqualified from being nominated as a member of Parliament if the person (a) is a State officer or other public officer, other than a member of Parliament; (b) has, at any time within the five years immediately preceding the date of election, held office as a member of the Commission; (c) has not been a citizen of Kenya for at least the ten years immediately preceding the date of election; (d) is a member of a county assembly; (e) is of unsound mind; (f) is an undischarged bankrupt; (g) is subject to a sentence of imprisonment of at least six months, as at the date of registration as a candidate, or at the date of election; or (h) is found, in accordance with any law, to have misused or abused a State office or public office or in any way to have contravened Chapter Six of the Constitution.; i) has previously been dismissed or removed fom public office for contravening the provisions of Articles 75, 76, 77 or 78 of the constitution; BUT - A person is not disqualified unless all possibility of appeal or review of the relevant sentence or decision has been exhausted.); (E6-18 - '(1) A person who directly or indirectly participates in any manner in any or public fundraising or harambee within eight months preceding a general election or during an election period, in any other case, shall be disqualified from contesting in the election held during that election year or election period, (2) this shall not apply to a fundraising for a person who is contesting an election under this Act or to a fundraising for a political party.); (E6-18(2) - '(1) A candidate for a parliamentary election shall be selected by persons who are members of the respective political parties and whose names appear on the party membership list as submitted to the Commission.'); (E6-20 - '(1) A person who is nominated by a political party under Article 97(1)(c) of the Constitution shall be a person who is a member of the political party on the date of submission of the party list by the political party'.); (E6-21 - where a party list is required (i.e., for the 12 available positions in the National Assembly that are allocated proportionally - see article 97(1c) of the constitution),'A party list submitted shall contain alternates between male and female candidates in the priority in which they are listed'.); (E6-24 - '(1) A public officer who intends to contest an election under this Act shall resign from public office at least six months before the date of election. (1A) A public officer who intends to contest in a by-election under this Act shall resign from public office within seven days of the declaration of a vacancy. (1B) This shall not apply to, (a) the President, (c) the Deputy President, (d) a member of Parliament, (e) a county governor, (f) a deputy county governor, (g) a member of a county assembly.';)} {Elections Regulations, Page; [see above - B2])} {(PP & PLists Regulations, Page 323-324 - '(1)  The conduct of party primaries [process of selecting candidates for election - doesn't include party lists] and party nomination of party lists [the process through which a political party elects or selects its candidates for party lists] shall, (a) be democratic, free and fair, (b) provide equal opportunities for all eligible candidates, (c) not discriminate against any eligible candidate, (d) be inclusive and participatory, (e) be open, transparent and accountable, (f) be credible,  and (g) be peaceful. (2) Every political party shall, upon submission of their nomination rules and procedures to the Commission pursuant to section 27 of the Act (a) make them available and accessible to the members of the party with specific considerations to members with disabilities, (b) place a copy at the party’s head office and branch offices, (c) post them on the party’s website. (3) Where the Commission determines that the party nomination rules and procedures do not conform to the requirements of the constitution of the political party, the Act and these Regulations, the Commission may require the political party to review and amend the party nomination rules and procedures so that they conform to the constitution of the political party, the Act and these Regulations. (4) Every political party shall prepare and communicate to its members a party nomination code of conduct at least thirty days before the conduct of party primaries or nomination of the party list, whichever is the earlier. (5) Every political party shall require an aspiring candidate to sign and ascribe to the party’s nomination code of conduct set out in Form 1 [see page 331] of the Schedule.') (Page 324-325 - '(1) Every political party shall appoint a national Election Board and may appoint county Election Boards in respect of every county where the party is offering candidates for election. (2) An Election Board shall comprise of not more than seven and not less than three members including one person to represent special interest groups, (3) An Election Board shall be responsible for conducting or supervising party primaries and party nomination of party lists and any other related activities for purposes of selection of candidates to participate in an election. (4) The Election Board shall notify members of the party of the date by which applications must be received, the date, time and venue of the party primary, (5) The nomination officials appointed by an Election Board shall conduct the party primary, tally the votes and present the results to an Election Board. (6) An Election Board shall declare the results in Form 2 [see page 331-332] set out in the Schedule and shall require the aspiring candidates or their agents to be present to sign the Form as acceptance of the process and the result.') (page 326 - '(1) Every political party may, at least two weeks before a party primary or nomination of the party lists, announce the fees to be levied by the party on every aspiring candidate. (2) An aspiring candidate shall submit to an Election Board of their party, a duly filled application in Form 3 [see page 333-334] set out in the Schedule together with, (a) a signed commitment to the political party’s constitution,npolicies and principles, (b) a self-declaration form as prescribed under the Leadership and Integrity Act, 2012, (c) copies of the person’s national identity card or valid passport, (d) copies of the candidate’s academic qualifications from the relevant institutions, (e) evidence of registration as a member of the party, and (f) a receipt or other evidence of payment of nomination fees. (3) Where an aspiring candidate intends to be nominated on the ground that the candidate is a person with disability, the candidate shall also submit an application in Form 4 [see page 334] set out in the Schedule which shall be certified by the National Council for Persons with Disabilities. (4) A person who wishes to be nominated by a political party to represent the youth shall be a person who has attained the age of eighteen years but has not attained the age of thirty five years and such person shall provide documentary proof of his or her age. (5) A party primary shall be conducted in accordance with the nomination rules and procedures of the party, (5A) the candidate who obtains the highest number of votes shall be declared the party nominee for the position. (5B) Where only one aspiring candidate applies to be nominated in any elective position, no party primary shall be conducted, (6) An Election Board shall in writing certify and declare the aspiring candidate as the party nominee, (7) Upon conclusion of the party primary, the authorized party officials shall certify the list of nominees and submit it to the Commission, (8) Upon receipt of the list by the Commission, the list shall not be altered.') (page 327 - '(1) Where the political party is required to issue a notice to its members regarding any exercise in the conduct of a party primary or nomination of party list, the party shall, (a) notify its members at least seven days before the date of the exercise, and (b) publish the notice in its website. (2) Every political party shall, at the time of submission of nominees to the Commission, file a statutory declaration signed by the person authorized to certify that candidate, to the effect that the political party has complied with the nomination rules and procedures of the party in the conduct of the party primary. (2A) The statutory declaration shall be in Form 5 [see page 334-335] set out in the Schedule. (2B) An aspiring candidate in a party primary or an applicant for nomination to a party list may appoint an agent to represent his or her interests during the exercise. (2C) An agent shall be appointed in writing by the candidate and shall (a) be a registered member of the political party, (b) be issued with an appointment letter by the aspiring candidate identifying him or her as the agent of that candidate; and (c) have access to information relating to the party primary.') (page 328 - '(1) A party list shall contain the names of all the persons who would stand elected if the party were to be entitled to all the seats available under Articles 97(1)(c) and shall alternate between male and female candidates [i.e., the 12 proportionally allocated seats in the National Assembly]. (1A) the  party list submitted shall ensure fair representation to take into consideration the principles of Article 81(b) and Article 100 of the Constitution. (2) The person authorized by the political party to certify that candidates have been nominated shall submit to the Commission the list of nominees and the party list together with a declaration in Form 6 [see page 335] set out in the Schedule, stating that the party’s nominations and preparation of party lists have complied with the Constitution, the Act and party nomination rules and procedures of the political party in the conduct of the party nomination to party lists. (3) Where, after scrutiny of the lists, the Commission is of the opinion that a party list does not conform to the requirements of Articles 97 (1)(c) of the Constitution, the Act or these Regulations, the Commission shall require the political party to review and amend the party list so that it conforms to the requirements of the law and guidelines by the Commission.') (page 328-329 - '(1) A political party that requests the Commission to supervise its party primary - in accordance with Article 88 of the constitution - shall be responsible for the preparatory work, (2) The Commission’s role in party primary shall be limited to the supervision, conduct, announcement and declaration of the results of the party primary on the day set aside for the primary and shall not participate in the preparation of party lists save as authorised under the law. (3) A party primary conducted and supervised by the Commission shall be, (a) through a secret ballot; and (b) determined by a majority of valid votes cast by the eligible voters. (4) The Commission shall publicly announce and declare the candidate who has obtained the highest number of valid votes to be duly nominated and shall issue a certificate to the duly nominated candidate. (5) In the event of a tie among the top candidates, the Commission shall hold a fresh party primary and the candidates in that party primary shall be only the candidates who garnered the highest number of votes. (6)  the Commission shall submit the results of the party primary to the Election Board of the party, (6A) The Election Board shall certify the list of nominees and the party authorized official shall formally submit the list to the Commission.') (page 330 - '(1) The Commission shall reject a party list or a name on the party list/list of nominees submitted by a political party where (a) the list does not conform to the requirements of the Constitution, the Act or these Regulations, or (b) the period for submitting revised party lists has lapsed. (2) Where the Commission rejects a party list or a nominee on the list, it shall require the political party to resubmit the party list or nominee within such period as the Commission may specify. (2A) A political party resubmitting a list shall resubmit the declaration under Regulation 18 to the effect that the political party has complied with the nomination rules and procedures of the party relating to the nomination of the names contained in the list. (2B) In the event that a political party fails to resubmit the party list or a name on the party list after it has been rejected, the party shall not be considered in the allocation of seats. (3) A person who has been nominated on a party list may decline the nomination by informing the political party and the Commission in writing, and the Commission shall replace that name with the next name of the same gender on the party list.') (page 330 - '(1) Every political party shall establish an internal dispute resolution mechanism in relation to the party primaries and party list. (1A) The dispute resolution mechanism of a party shall be independent of the party leadership and other party institutions. (1B) The dispute resolution mechanism of a party shall hear and determine all nomination disputes not later than ninety days before the date of general election. (2) The contravention of any of the provisions of the Election Offences Act (2016) or the breach of the Electoral Code of Conduct shall constitute electoral malpractice in relation to a party primary and party nomination of party lists.')
B4CANLAW2TXT: (Elections Act E6-20/21 - where a party list is required (i.e., for the 12 available positions in the National Assembly that are allocated proportionally - see article 97(1c) of the constitution),'A party list submitted shall contain alternates between male and female candidates in the priority in which they are listed'); (PP & PLists Regulations, page 328 - '(1) A party list shall contain the names of all the persons who would stand elected if the party were to be entitled to all the seats available under Articles 97(1)(c) and shall alternate between male and female candidates [i.e., the 12 proportionally allocated seats in the National Assembly]. (1A) the party list submitted shall ensure fair representation to take into consideration the principles of Article 81(b) and Article 100 of the Constitution.); (Constitution - Article 100 of the constituitution says that parliament shall enact laws to ensure representation of maginalised groups (including women) ; 'Article 27(8) of the Constitution of Kenya provides that the State shall take steps to ensure that not more than two-thirds of members of all elective and appointive positions are not of the same gender. BUT, there is yet to be enacted specific legislations to operationalize these constitutional provision on gender broadly across the lower house); (IT IS SAFE TO PRESUME THAT THE COUNTY WOMAN REPRESENTATIVE NOMINEES MUST BE FEMALE (THOUGH THIS IS NOT EXPLICITLY STATED) - NB: LOWER HOUSE INCLUDES 47 WOMEN FROM EACH CONSTITUENCY (Article 97(1b) Constitution of Kenya)
B18CANWOMTXT: [Page 88 - "The Party lists (in particular for the 12 special interest seats in the National Assembly) shall alternate between male and female candidates in the priority in which they are listed and shall reflect the regional and ethnic diversity of the people of Kenya."] [Page 104 - "In nominating or electing persons to public offices, the party shall at all times take into account the competence integrity and honesty of the nominees, social, cultural, geographical and religious diversity of Kenya, and the principles of youth and gender equity and disability."]
B20CANETHTX: [Page 88 - "The Party lists (in particular for the 12 special interest seats in the National Assembly) shall alternate between male and female candidates in the priority in which they are listed and shall reflect the regional and ethnic diversity of the people of Kenya."] [Page 104 - "In nominating or electing persons to public offices, the party shall at all times take into account the competence integrity and honesty of the nominees, social, cultural, geographical and religious diversity of Kenya, and the principles of youth and gender equity and disability."] [Nomination Rules & Regulations, Page 24 - '(1) The National Assembly Party List (i.e., for the 12 special seats - Article 97(1)(c) Constituion of kenya) shall be prepared pursuant to and be in strict compliance with the Constitution of Kenya and Elections Act of Kenya and shall reflect the ethnic diversity of Kenya]
B28CANSELTXT: [IEBC - Candidates self-nominate]; [Party Statute, (Page 84 - '(1) The party shall conduct open, free, fair and transparent nominations in national elections through consensus, secret ballot, or through the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) or other democratic method acceptable to the members under the supervision of the National Elections Board and the County Elections Board.') (Page 85 - 'Unless otherwise provided for in a written agreement between the Party and any other Party or parties or coalition of parties; any parliamentary candidate seeking nomination on a Party ticket shall: (1). Apply in writing to the Elections Board and provide copies of the following: A. Detailed Curriculum Vitae, B. National Identity Card, C. Voter’s Card or evidence of registration as a voter, D. Academic and / or professional certificates, (2). Pay to the Party a non-refundable nomination fee as may be determined by the NEC from time to time, (3). Be nominated in accordance with the Party Nomination Rules and Regulations, (4). Meet the requirements under the Kenyan Constitution, this Constitution and the Electoral laws or any other law for the time being in force in the Republic of Kenya, (5). Sign an agreement with the Party binding themself to abide by all duties and obligations required of them under the Party Constitution') (Page 87 - '(1) Nothing in this Article shall preclude the Party from declining to present a candidate for any elective position in a general election or a by-election once the matter is upon the agenda, discussed and resolved by the National Executive Committee in consultation with the National Elections Board.') (Page 88 - '(1) Pursuant to, and in accordance with the Constitution of Kenya and other relevant Acts of Parliament, the Party shall submit to the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission Party lists containing Twelve (12) persons for consideration as nominated Members of the National Assembly to represent special interests including the youth, persons with disabilities and workers, (2) The Party lists shall alternate between male and female candidates in the priority in which they are listed and shall reflect the regional and ethnic diversity of the people of Kenya, (3) Persons who are nominated to the respective party lists shall be persons who meet the requirements of any written law as well as academic and professional qualifications to be elected to parliament.') (Page 93 - '(1) The National Elections Board shall present to the National Executive Committee a list of all candidates contesting party positions or elections for presidential parliamentary or county level positions PROVIDED that the National Executive Committee may raise an objection with valid and very good reasons observing fairness and justice regarding the suitability of any candidate, and such objection shall be final.') (Page 97 - '(1)The National Elections Appeals Tribunal shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine disputes arising from party nominations and elections, (2) Any member aggrieved in respect of all other party elections and / or nominations shall lodge a complaint with the National Elections Appeals Tribunal, (3) The decision of National Elections Appeals Tribunal shall be final.') (Page 98 - '(1) Leaders of the Party shall bind themselves by signing the Party’s Code of Conduct.') (Page 104 - '(1) In nominating or electing persons to the party or public offices, the party shall at all times take into account the competence integrity and honesty of the nominees, social, cultural, geographical and religious diversity of Kenya, and the principles of youth and gender equity and disability, (2) The term of office for all elected leaders under this constitution shall be five (5) years commencing on the date of ratification of this constitution, (3) Nothing in this constitution, its rules, regulations or procedures shall preclude the NEC acting on its own or through the National Coordinating Committee from taking or making decision that it deems proper and fit in the interest of the Party.') (Page - '(1)    ]; [Nomination Rules & Regulations, Page 7 - '(1) "Voter" for the purposes of Parliamentary nominations means a Jubilee Party member who is a holder of a National Identity Card and is registered as a voter in that particular electoral area.') (Page 7 - '(1) the National Executive Committee shall have the final authority ... in determining the results of and actual election and or selection, and preparation and authentication of the list of Party nominees, to contest various elective and non-elective positions available to the people of Kenya (being members of the Party), (2) the NEC is the ultimate organ of the Party for determining the persons who succeed (by election or selection) in obtaining any nomination of the Party."] [Page 8 - '(1) A person is eligible for nomination as a Jubilee Party candidate if he/she - 1.1. is a citizen of Kenya, 1.2 is a registered Party member, 1.3 is qualified to stand for any elective or selective position in accordance with the laws of Kenya (page 35 - especially, Constitution of Kenya Article 99; The Elections Act Article 22, Article 23, Article 26), 1.4 is a registered voter, 1.5 has signed the party Pledge, 1.6 his/her proposed nomination is seconded by a minimum number of registered Jubilee Party members as applies to the particular candidate position, 1.7 Seconders: - The minimum number of seconders is provided below: - 1.7.1 Women Representative - 2, National Assembly Representative - 2.'] [Page 9 - '(1) A person is not qualified for nomination as a Jubilee Party candidate if the person - 1.1 owes allegiance to a foreign state, 1.2 is a State officer, or is acting in any State office (other than President, Deputy President, Governor, Deputy Governor, member of Parliament (the National Assembly or the Senate), member of a County Assembly), 1.3 is subject to a sentence of imprisonment exceeding six months imposed on him by such a court or substituted by competent authority for some other sentence imposed on him by such a court unless all possibility of appeal of review of the relevant sentence or decision has not been exhausted, 1.4 is of unsound mind, 1.5 is in violation of Chapter 6 of the Constitution of Kenya; or any other law on Integrity, 1.6 is bankrupt under the laws of Kenya, 1.7 has not paid the prescribed nomination fees as shall be determined by NEC, 1.8 has not produced all necessary identification documents required by the Party, 1.9 is by virtue of his own act of admission, under acknowledgement of allegiance, obedience or adherence to another political party.'] [Page 9 -10 - '(1) All persons seeking to contest National Assembly member or Women Representative Election on a Jubilee Party ticket (nomination) shall register to the Jubilee Party in respect of any election for which these Rules apply and shall - 1.1 Apply to the National Elections Board in the prescribed manner, 1.2 Submit with the application a duly completed and signed Code of Conduct to the party, 1.3 Fully and truthfully answer all questions posed by the Party, and supply all information that the Party may require in the application accurately and truthfully, 1.4 Submit his application to the National Election Board within the timeframe published by the National Elections Board, 1.5 Pay an application and nomination fee as shall be determined by the National Executive Committee.']; [Page 10 - ' (1) Upon receipt of the list of aspirants by the National Elections Board, such list shall be forwarded to the National Executive Committee.'] [Page 10 - '(1) The National Executive Committee shall in general be responsible for receiving and considering the various Provisional Party Nomination Lists from the National Elections Board, (2) In addition to and/or pursuant to the powers granted to it by the Party Constitution, the National Executive Committee has the power pursuant to these Rules to consider objections in respect of any candidate and on its motion to review the suitability of any person presented for Party nomination before or after the nomination - the National Executive Committee shall have the final decision on whether to accept or otherwise such a candidate.'] [Page 11 - The National Elections Board shall in general undertake the following functions - (1) 'conducting of the vetting of candidates for nomination and or election of the Party Candidates, (2) Overseeing and providing materials, directions and guidelines for the conduct of the vetting'] [Page 12 - '(1) The powers and functions of the National Elections Board may be delegated outsourced, or subcontracted to any entity which the National Executive Committee may deem necessary to achieve the objective of a free fair and credible nomination.'] [Page 15 - '(1) Nominations will constitute universal suffrage on a day designated by the National Elections Board and the County Elections Board. (2) The National Elections Board shall provide alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.' ] [Page 17 - '(1) Registration of party voters and revision of the register of voters under these regulations shall be carried out at all times, save that registration of party voters shall close one month or such other time as the NEC determine, but before the date on which parties are required to submit party membership lists to the IEBC, (2) Any person who has attained the age of eighteen years and is a holder of a national identity card or a Kenyan passport and whose name is not in the party membership and or register of voters of any other party may be registered as a voter under these rules upon application. (3) The National Elections Board shall announce the Nomination Day or days which shall be no more than thirty days before the day by which parties are required by law to have nominated candidates.'] [Page 18 - '(1) Any candidate, who on nomination day either by himself, his agents or supporters engages, permits or condones any acts of violence, whatsoever and howsoever may be disqualified. The Presiding Officer shall record and report on such a behavior within the Polling Centre and the decision made thereof.'] [Page 19 - (1) On nomination day(s), candidates duly cleared by the National Elections Board shall present themselves or by their designated agents be present before their respective Returning Officers with the Party Compliance Certificate.']; [Page 20 - '(1) Voting shall be done by Secret Ballot or as otherwise determined by the Elections Board, (2) All eligible voters shall identify themselves by holding their National Identity Cards before commencement of voting, (3) If only one person presents themselves for nomination by the day set aside for submission of applications for nomination as a candidate for a position under these rules, that candidate shall be declared duly nominated on the day designated by the National Elections Board for nominations.' ]; [Page 22 - '(1) In the event that there is a tie in the votes cast during the nomination process for any position the candidates, who received the greatest number of votes shall be subjected to a fresh election. Such fresh election must be held within seven days after the original election, (2) Any Candidates taking part in the elections and who is dissatisfied with the results shall be entitled to appeal to the National Elections Appeal Tribunal within 72 hours (3 Days) of the nomination results being announced by the Returning Officer, (3) These Rules shall prescribe the fees to be paid upon the lodging of an appeal, which fees will be calculated so as to cater wholly or partially for the reasonable sitting allowances for the members of the appellate Tribunal for sitting to hear and determine the appeal and secretarial services provided therefor, while taking in due consideration the economic realities of Kenya so as not to unduly discourage appeals.']; [Page 23 - (1) The appeal shall be lodged in the prescribed format (simply by writing to the appellate Tribunal and delivering the same to any member of the appellate Tribunal) and by paying the prescribed fee as per the rules and the schedule (2) Should the nomination or selection process be found and determined to be flawed and declared null and void by an Elections Appeals Tribunal upon an appeal within the time provided, the National Elections Board shall announce the dates and venue for fresh elections and, in the case of Presidential and Deputy Presidential nominations, conduct a repeat elections, and in any other case direct the County Elections Board for the affected County to conduct a repeat election, in the manner prescribed for conducting an election in these Rules. (2) Should the National Elections Appeals Tribunal hearing an appeal conclusively arrive at a decision, upon sufficient proof being adduced, that a candidate has secured his nomination through undue influence, corruption or other fraudulent means, it shall immediately make its decision known to the National Elections Board, which Board may proceed to set aside and nullify such nomination and have power to declare a winner or call for a re- election, (3) The decision of the National Elections Board shall be a subject of appeal to the National Appeals Tribunal whose decision shall be final.']; [Page 24-25 - '(1) The qualifications for the candidates to be in the National Assembly Party List [i.e., for the 12 special seats - Article 97(1)(c) of the Constitution of Kenya] shall be the same as that of candidates to the National Assembly with exception of the requirements relating to supporters, (2) The National Assembly Party List shall be prepared pursuant to and be in strict compliance with the Constitution and Elections Act of Kenya and shall reflect the ethnic diversity of Kenya, (3) The procedures to be employed in identifying the candidates for nomination shall require that all persons seeking to apply for nomination as a Member of National Assembly on a Jubilee Party List shall register to the Jubilee Party in respect of any nomination for which these Rules apply and shall: a. Apply to the National Elections Board in the prescribed manner, b. Submit with the application a duly completed and signed Code of Conduct to the party, c. Fully and truthfully answer all questions posed by the Party, and supply all information that the Party may require in the application accurately and truthfully, d. Submit his application to the National Election Board within the timeframe published by the National Elections Board, e. Pay a nomination fee as shall be determined by the National Executive Committee from time to time. (4) Upon receipt of the list of aspirants by the National Elections Board, such list shall be forwarded to the National Executive Committee. (5) The National Executive Committee shall from time to time determine and provide the schedule of fees payable for nomination for the various positions.
