The National Executive Committee determined the nomination fees payable as per the attached schedule. (6) The National Executive Committee shall from time to time determine and provide the schedule of fees payable for appeals under these rules. (7) The National Executive Committee may issue orders for the better carrying into the effect of these Rules'] [Page 28/36 - '(1) Nomination fees for aspirants - Women Representatives: Ksh 250,000, Member of Parliament: Ksh 250,000; (2) All Women, Youth and People with Disabilities (PWD) shall pay half the amounts for the respective position. However, the 50% discount will not be extended to Parliamentary women representatives with respect to women.']; [Page 28  - '(1) List of Requirements (+ certified copies of each) - a) Two passport size photographs, b) Original Identification Card or Passport used to register as a voter, c) Registered as a voter with IEBC (Confirm status at ORPP or IEBC website), d) HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS BOARD (HELB) CERTIFICATE, e) CERTIFICATE OF GOOD CONDUCT, f) ETHICS AND ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION (EACC) CERTIFICATE, g) KENYA REVENUE AUTHORITY (KRA) CERTIFICATE, h) CREDIT REFERENCE BUREAU (CRB) CERTIFICATE, i) ACADEMIC CERTIFICATES, j) PIN CERTIFICATE, k) JUBILEE MEMBERSHIP CARD, l) RESIGNATION LETTER FROM OTHER PARTIES, m) NOMINATION FEE RECEIPT, n) REGISTRATION FEE RECEIPT, o) CHECK PARTY MEMBERSHIP STATUS (RPP) www.orpp.or.ke,']
B35PRESBALLOTTXT: {(Party must be registered with the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC - hereafter 'the Commission) to be able to participate in any election' (see A4RECPARTYTXT);} {(Elections Act, page E6-13 - '1) A political party shall nominate its candidates for an election under this Act at least ninety days before a general election under this Act in accordance with its constitution and nomination rules. (2) A political party shall not change the candidate nominated after the nomination of that person has been received by the Commission: Provided that in the event of the death, resignation or incapacity of the nominated candidate or of the violation of the electoral code of conduct by the nominated candidate, the political party may after notifying the candidate that the party seeks to substitute, where applicable, substitute its candidate before the date of presentation of nomination papers to the Commission. (3) A political party shall hear and determine all intra party disputes arising from political party nominations within thirty days. (3) Notwithstanding subsection (1), in the case of any other election, the Commission shall by notice in the prescribed form, specify the day or days upon which political parties shall nominate candidates to contest in a presidential election in accordance with its constitution or rules, which shall be at least fifty-five days before such election. (4) A presidential candidate or a political party shall not at any time change the person nominated as a deputy presidential candidate after the nomination of that person has been received by the Commission: Provided that in the event of death, resignation or incapacity of the nominated candidate or of the violation of the electoral code of conduct by the nominated candidate, the political party may substitute its candidate before the date of presentation of nomination papers to the Commission.'); (page E6-16 - '(1) A person may be nominated as a candidate for an election under this Act only if that person, (a) is qualified to be elected to that office under the Constitution and this Act, (b) if the person is a holder of a degree from a university recognised in Kenya.'); (page E6-17 - '(1) A person qualifies for nomination as a presidential candidate if the person (a) is a citizen by birth, (b) is qualified to stand for election as a member of Parliament [see page E6-17], (c) is nominated by a political party, and (d) is nominated by not fewer than two thousand voters from each of a majority of the counties. (2) A person is not qualified for nomination as a presidential candidate if the person (a) owes allegiance to a foreign state, or (b) is a public officer, or is acting in any State or other public office. (3) Subsection (2)(b) shall not apply to (a) the President, (b) the Deputy President, or (c) a member of Parliament.') (E6-17 - '(1) A person is disqualified from being elected a member of Parliament [see (b) above] if the person, (a) has, at any time within the five years immediately preceding the date of election, held office as a member of the Commission, (b) has not been a citizen of Kenya for at least the ten years immediately preceding the date of election, (c) is of unsound mind, (d) is an undischarged bankrupt, (e) is subject to a sentence of imprisonment of at least six months, as at the date of registration as a candidate, or at the date of election, (f) is found, in accordance with any law, to have misused or abused a State office or public office or in any way to have contravened Chapter Six of the Constitution. (2) A person is not disqualified unless all possibility of appeal or review of the relevant sentence or decision has been exhausted.'); (E6-18 - '(1) A person who directly or indirectly participates in any manner in any or public fundraising or harambee within eight months preceding a general election or during an election period, in any other case, shall be disqualified from contesting in the election held during that election year or election period. (2) Subsection (1) shall not apply to a fundraising for a person who is contesting an election under this Act or to a fundraising for a political party.') (E6-18(1) -'(1) A political party shall submit its nomination rules to the Commission at least six months before the nomination of its candidates. (2) Upon receipt of the nomination rules from a political party, the Commission shall, within fourteen days, review the rules to ensure compliance with the prescribed regulations and (a) issue the political party with a certificate of compliance, or (b) require the political party to amend the rules to ensure such compliance within fourteen days. (2A) For purposes of subsection (2), the Commission shall, by notice in the Gazette, issue Regulations prescribing guidelines to be complied with and the process by which political parties nominate candidates for nomination in accordance with Article 88 (4)(d) of the Constitution. (3) A political party that nominates a person for an election under this Act shall submit to the Commission a membership list of the party (a) in the case of a general election, at least one hundred and twenty days before the date of the election, and (b) in the case of a by-election, forty-five days before the date of the by-election. (4) The persons who nominate a presidential candidate shall be members of the candidate’s political party.'); (E6-18(2) - '(1) A person qualifies to be nominated by a political party for presidential elections if that person, (a) is selected in the manner provided for in the constitution or rules of the political party concerned relating to members of that party who wish to contest presidential elections, and (b) subject to subsection (4) (according to which - 'the authorised person or persons as per subsection (3) [subsection (3) - 'every political party shall notify the Commission of the name of the person(s) authorised by the party to certify to the Commission that a person has or persons have been selected by the party + the person(s) so named must deposit their specimen signature with the Commission in such a manner as the Commission may require'] shall, in writing, certify that a candidate has been nominated by the party'), the party certifies the nomination to the Commission. (2) Every political party shall submit the names of the party candidates who have been selected to participate in the general elections under this Act at least sixty days before the elections, (2A) A political party shall, at least twenty-one days before the nomination day, submit to the Commission the names of the persons contesting in its party primary and the date of its party primary. (2B) A candidate for a presidential, election shall be selected by persons who are members of the respective political parties and whose names appear on the party membership list as submitted to the Commission.'); (page E6-24 - '(1) A public officer who intends to contest an election under this Act shall resign from public office at least six months before the date of election. (1A) A public officer who intends to contest in a by-election under this Act shall resign from public office within seven days of the declaration of a vacancy. (2) This section shall not apply to, (a) the President, (c) the Deputy President, (d) a member of Parliament, (e) a county governor, (f) a deputy county governor, (g) a member of a county assembly.'); (page E6-42 - '(1) Every political party and every person who participates in an election under the Constitution and this Act shall subscribe to and observe the Electoral Code of Conduct set out in the Second Schedule of the Elections Act [2011 - see E6-45-E6-52]. (2) A political party that is eligible to nominate candidates under the Constitution, this Act or any other written law shall not be eligible to contest in any election unless the political party and the candidate have subscribed to the Electoral Code of Conduct.');} {(Elections Regulations, Page 91 - '(1) A political party that intends to nominate a candidate for an elective post under the Elections Act (hereafter 'the Act') shall observe the provisions of the Constitution, the Act and any other written law in respect of the qualifications and disqualifications for that office. (1A) A political party whose nomination rules have been declared void by the Commission under section 27(2B) of the Act shall not participate in the elections. (2) The Commission shall reject a candidate submitted by a political party for any elective post if the candidate is not qualified or eligible for election under the Constitution, the Act or any other written law. (3) Each political party shall issue a nomination certificate, duly signed by the authorized party officials, to the candidate nominated to participate in the elections. (4) The Commission shall reject a nomination certificate which has any alterations. (5) Each political party shall submit to the Commission a party membership list as prescribed in Form 11A [see page 121]. (5A) Each political party shall submit only the name of one person as their candidate for a presidential election. (6) Each political party shall submit to the Commission the date, venue and names of persons contesting in presidential party primaries in both printed and electronic format set out in Form 11B [see page 121]. (7) Every political party shall submit the name of the party candidate who has been selected/nominated to participate in the  (presidential) general elections in both printed and electronic format as prescribed in Form 11H [see page 124]. (8) Each political party intending to present a candidate in an election shall, after its nominations and on such date or within such period as the Commission may designate, submit a list of persons nominated as (direct) candidates indicating the elective posts to which they are seeking election. (8A) The list submitted shall be signed by the authorised official of the political party.'); (page 92-93 - '(1) A political party candidate at a presidential election shall be nominated by a political party by and delivery to the Commission on the day fixed for the nomination of candidates at that election, an application for nomination in Form 12 set out in the Schedule [see page 128]. (2) An application for nomination under this regulation shall be, (a) signed by the candidate, and the authorised official of the party, (b) delivered to the Commission personally by the candidate or by an official of the party. (3) The person delivering an application for nomination for presidency shall at least five days to the day fixed for nomination, deliver to the Commission a list bearing the names, respective signatures, identity card or passport numbers of at least two thousand voters registered in each of a majority of the counties [i.e., at least 24 counties], in standard A4 sheets of paper and in an electronic form. (3A) The sheets of paper delivered under this regulation shall (a) be serially numbered, (b) each have at the top, in typescript, the wording at the top of Form 12, and (c) be accompanied by copies of the identification document of the voters. (4) There shall be delivered to the returning officer together with the application for nomination, a statutory declaration in Form 13 set out in the Schedule [see page 129], made not earlier than one month before the nomination day. (5) An application for nomination for candidature at a presidential election shall be accompanied by a non-refundable nomination fee, in banker’s draft of (a) one hundred thousand shillings for a candidate who is a youth, a woman or a person with disability, and (b) two hundred thousand shillings for any other candidate. (6) If at the close of nominations for a presidential election, only one candidate is validly nominated, the Commission shall publish a notice in the Gazette showing the name of the candidate so nominated and stating that the presidential election shall not be held, and the Commission shall declare the candidate elected as President in Form 14  [see page 130].'); (page 96 - '(1) A nomination paper submitted by a political party candidate to the Commission shall (a) contain the candidate’s name as it appears in the register of voters, (b) be signed by the candidate and by a proposer and seconder who shall be voters registered in the respective electoral areas, and who shall be members of the political party, and by an authorised official of the political party; and (c) be delivered to the returning officer personally by the candidate or by a person authorised by the candidate in that behalf on the day set for the nomination. (2) Where a candidate has applied for nomination in accordance with these Regulations, unless the returning officer holds a nomination paper invalid in accordance with these Regulations [see page 96-97 for reasons that nomination paper may be considered invalid], or the candidate withdraws his or her candidature, or proof is given to the satisfaction of the returning officer of the candidates’ death, the candidate named therein shall stand validly nominated = ballot access.'); (page 97 - '(1) A candidate whose nomination papers have been delivered to the returning officer may, before the close of nominations, by notice in writing signed by him or her before the returning officer and presented to the returning officer, withdraw his or her candidature. (2) No person shall be a subscriber (proposer or seconder - see above) to more than one nomination paper in respect of different candidates in the same election and if any person subscribes to more than one nomination paper such subscription shall be inoperative (void) on nomination papers (unless this is caused by the candidate they previously subscribed, dying or withdrawing from election). (3) A candidate shall obtain and submit a self-declaration form (ethical requirements) as prescribed under the Leadership and Integrity Act, 2012 (No. 19 of 2012).'); (page 98 - '(1) a person seeking nomination shall submit to the Commission certified copies of certificates of their educational qualification. (1A) Where the body that issued the certificate is not based in Kenya, a candidate shall be required to seek authentication of that body with the Kenya National Examinations Council, in the case of form four certificates, or the Commission for University Education, in the case of university degrees. (2) No person shall be entitled to attend the proceedings taking place during the time fixed for the delivery of nomination papers unless that person is, (a) a candidate, (b) a person nominated as deputy to the candidate, where applicable, (c) an agent, or, (d) present for the purpose of assisting the returning officer at the request of the returning officer, (2A) Only two persons shall be entitled to attend these proceedings at any one time, in respect of any one candidate, whether one of the two persons is the candidate himself or herself or not, (3) A person entitled to attend these proceedings shall also be entitled to inspect and to object to the validity of any nomination paper delivered in his or her presence'); (page 99 -'(1)  A candidate who has been nominated may withdraw his or her candidature by delivering to the respective returning officer a notice to that effect in Form 24A [see page 139-140] not later than three days after nomination. (2) Where there are only two nominated candidates and one candidate withdraws, the remaining candidate shall be declared duly elected in accordance with regulation 53.'); (page 101 - '(1) Every political party shall at least fourteen days to the date of the election submit to the Commission the names of one national chief elections agent and forty-seven county chief elections agents.'); (page 114 - '(1) Where pursuant to Article 138(5) of the Constitution, no candidate is elected as president, the Commission shall at the time of publishing the results, publish a notice in the Gazette indicating that no candidate has been elected president. (2) The Commission shall within two days of this notice, publish a notice for a fresh election for president in Form 40  set out in the Schedule [see page 164]. (3) Where no candidate is elected in a presidential election a fresh election shall be held within thirty days after the previous election in accordance with Article 138 of the Constitution. (3A) These Regulations shall, with the necessary modifications and adaptations, apply to the fresh election.'); (page 116 - '(1) Where in these Regulations expression is used requiring, authorizing, or implying that, any act is to be done in the presence of the candidates or agents, that expression shall be regarded as reference to the presence of such candidates or agents as may be required or authorized to attend. (1A) The mere non-attendance of any candidate or agents at the time and place as contemplated under subregulation (1) shall not, if any act is otherwise lawfully done, invalidate this act.');} {(PP & PLists Regulations, Page - '(1)' [as below - B36])}
B36PRESCANLAWTXT: {(Elections Act, page E6-13 - '(1) A political party shall hear and determine all intra party disputes arising from political party nominations within thirty days. (2) A presidential candidate or a political party shall not at any time change the person nominated as a deputy presidential candidate after the nomination of that person has been received by the Commission: Provided that in the event of death, resignation or incapacity of the nominated candidate or of the violation of the electoral code of conduct by the nominated candidate, the political party may substitute its candidate before the date of presentation of nomination papers to the Commission.'); (page E6-16 - '(1) A person may be nominated as a candidate for an election under this Act only if that person, (a) is qualified to be elected to that office under the Constitution and this Act, (b) if the person is a holder of a degree from a university recognised in Kenya.'); (page E6-17 - '(1) A person qualifies for nomination as a presidential candidate if the person (a) is a citizen by birth, (b) is qualified to stand for election as a member of Parliament [see page E6-17], (c) is nominated by a political party, and (d) is nominated by not fewer than two thousand voters from each of a majority of the counties. (2) A person is not qualified for nomination as a presidential candidate if the person (a) owes allegiance to a foreign state, or (b) is a public officer, or is acting in any State or other public office. (3) Subsection (2)(b) shall not apply to (a) the President, (b) the Deputy President, or (c) a member of Parliament.') (E6-17 - '(1) A person is disqualified from being elected a member of Parliament [see (b) above] if the person, (a) has, at any time within the five years immediately preceding the date of election, held office as a member of the Commission, (b) has not been a citizen of Kenya for at least the ten years immediately preceding the date of election, (c) is of unsound mind, (d) is an undischarged bankrupt, (e) is subject to a sentence of imprisonment of at least six months, as at the date of registration as a candidate, or at the date of election, (f) is found, in accordance with any law, to have misused or abused a State office or public office or in any way to have contravened Chapter Six of the Constitution. (2) A person is not disqualified unless all possibility of appeal or review of the relevant sentence or decision has been exhausted.'); (E6-18 - '(1) A person who directly or indirectly participates in any manner in any or public fundraising or harambee within eight months preceding a general election or during an election period, in any other case, shall be disqualified from contesting in the election held during that election year or election period. (2) Subsection (1) shall not apply to a fundraising for a person who is contesting an election under this Act or to a fundraising for a political party.'); (E6-18(1) -'(1) The persons who nominate a presidential candidate shall be members of the candidate’s political party.'); (E6-18(2) - '(1) A person qualifies to be nominated by a political party for presidential elections if that person, (a) is selected in the manner provided for in the constitution or rules of the political party concerned relating to members of that party who wish to contest presidential elections, and (b) subject to subsection (4) (according to which - 'the authorised person or persons as per subsection (3) [subsection (3) - 'every political party shall notify the Commission of the name of the person(s) authorised by the party to certify to the Commission that a person has or persons have been selected by the party + the person(s) so named must deposit their specimen signature with the Commission in such a manner as the Commission may require'] shall, in writing, certify that a candidate has been nominated by the party'), the party certifies the nomination to the Commission. (2) Every political party shall submit the names of the party candidates who have been selected to participate in the general elections under this Act at least sixty days before the elections, (2A) A political party shall, at least twenty-one days before the nomination day, submit to the Commission the names of the persons contesting in its party primary and the date of its party primary. (2B) A candidate for a presidential, election shall be selected by persons who are members of the respective political parties and whose names appear on the party membership list as submitted to the Commission.'); (page E6-24 - '(1) A public officer who intends to contest an election under this Act shall resign from public office at least six months before the date of election. (1A) A public officer who intends to contest in a by-election under this Act shall resign from public office within seven days of the declaration of a vacancy. (2) This section shall not apply to, (a) the President, (c) the Deputy President, (d) a member of Parliament, (e) a county governor, (f) a deputy county governor, (g) a member of a county assembly.');} {(Elections Regulations, Page - '(1)' [as above - B35]);} {(PP & PLists Regulatiosn, Page 323-324 - '(1) The conduct of party primaries [process of selecting candidates for election - doesn't include party lists] and party nomination of party lists [the process through which a political party elects or selects its candidates for party lists] shall, (a) be democratic, free and fair, (b) provide equal opportunities for all eligible candidates, (c) not discriminate against any eligible candidate, (d) be inclusive and participatory, (e) be open, transparent and accountable, (f) be credible, and (g) be peaceful. (2) Every political party shall, upon submission of their nomination rules and procedures to the Commission pursuant to section 27 of the Act (a) make them available and accessible to the members of the party with specific considerations to members with disabilities, (b) place a copy at the party’s head office and branch offices, (c) post them on the party’s website. (3) Where the Commission determines that the party nomination rules and procedures do not conform to the requirements of the constitution of the political party, the Act and these Regulations, the Commission may require the political party to review and amend the party nomination rules and procedures so that they conform to the constitution of the political party, the Act and these Regulations. (4) Every political party shall prepare and communicate to its members a party nomination code of conduct at least thirty days before the conduct of party primaries or nomination of the party list, whichever is the earlier. (5) Every political party shall require an aspiring candidate to sign and ascribe to the party’s nomination code of conduct set out in Form 1 [see page 331] of the Schedule.'); (Page 324-325 - '(1) Every political party shall appoint a national Election Board and may appoint county Election Boards in respect of every county where the party is offering candidates for election. (2) An Election Board shall comprise of not more than seven and not less than three members including one person to represent special interest groups, (3) An Election Board shall be responsible for conducting or supervising party primaries and party nomination of party lists and any other related activities for purposes of selection of candidates to participate in an election. (4) The Election Board shall notify members of the party of the date by which applications must be received, the date, time and venue of the party primary, (5) The nomination officials appointed by an Election Board shall conduct the party primary, tally the votes and present the results to an Election Board. (6) An Election Board shall declare the results in Form 2 [see page 331-332] set out in the Schedule and shall require the aspiring candidates or their agents to be present to sign the Form as acceptance of the process and the result.'); (page 326 - '(1) Every political party may, at least two weeks before a party primary or nomination of the party lists, announce the fees to be levied by the party on every aspiring candidate. (2) An aspiring candidate shall submit to an Election Board of their party, a duly filled application in Form 3 [see page 333-334] set out in the Schedule together with, (a) a signed commitment to the political party’s constitution, policies and principles, (b) a self-declaration form as prescribed under the Leadership and Integrity Act, 2012, (c) copies of the person’s national identity card or valid passport, (d) copies of the candidate’s academic qualifications from the relevant institutions, (e) evidence of registration as a member of the party, and (f) a receipt or other evidence of payment of nomination fees. (3) Where an aspiring candidate intends to be nominated on the ground that the candidate is a person with disability, the candidate shall also submit an application in Form 4 [see page 334] set out in the Schedule which shall be certified by the National Council for Persons with Disabilities. (4) A party primary shall be conducted in accordance with the nomination rules and procedures of the party, (4A) the candidate who obtains the highest number of votes shall be declared the party nominee for the position. (4B) Where only one aspiring candidate applies to be nominated in any elective position, no party primary shall be conducted, (5) An Election Board shall in writing certify and declare the aspiring candidate as the party nominee, (6) Upon conclusion of the party primary, the authorized party officials shall certify the list of nominees and submit it to the Commission, (7) Upon receipt of the list by the Commission, the list shall not be altered.'); (page 327 - '(1) Where the political party is required to issue a notice to its members regarding any exercise in the conduct of a party primary the party shall, (a) notify its members at least seven days before the date of the exercise, and (b) publish the notice in its website. (2) Every political party shall, at the time of submission of nominees to the Commission, file a statutory declaration signed by the person authorized to certify that candidate, to the effect that the political party has complied with the nomination rules and procedures of the party in the conduct of the party primary. (2A) The statutory declaration shall be in Form 5 [see page 334-335] set out in the Schedule. (2B) An aspiring candidate in a party primary may appoint an agent to represent his or her interests during the exercise. (2C) An agent shall be appointed in writing by the candidate and shall (a) be a registered member of the political party, (b) be issued with an appointment letter by the aspiring candidate identifying him or her as the agent of that candidate; and (c) have access to information relating to the party primary.'); (page 328-329 - '(1) A political party that requests the Commission to supervise its party primary - in accordance with Article 88 of the constitution - shall be responsible for the preparatory work, (2) The Commission’s role in party primary shall be limited to the supervision, conduct, announcement and declaration of the results of the party primary on the day set aside for the primary and shall not participate in the preparation of party lists save as authorised under the law. (3) A party primary conducted and supervised by the Commission shall be, (a) through a secret ballot; and (b) determined by a majority of valid votes cast by the eligible voters. (4) The Commission shall publicly announce and declare the candidate who has obtained the highest number of valid votes to be duly nominated and shall issue a certificate to the duly nominated candidate. (5) In the event of a tie among the top candidates, the Commission shall hold a fresh party primary and the candidates in that party primary shall be only the candidates who garnered the highest number of votes. (6)  the Commission shall submit the results of the party primary to the Election Board of the party, (6A) The Election Board shall certify the list of nominees and the party authorized official shall formally submit the list to the Commission.'); (page 330 - '(1) The Commission shall reject a list or a name on the list of nominees submitted by a political party where (a) the list does not conform to the requirements of the Constitution, the Act or these Regulations, or (b) the period for submitting a revised list/nominee has lapsed. (2) Where the Commission rejects a party's list or a nominee on the list, it shall require the political party to resubmit the list or nominee within such period as the Commission may specify. (2A) A political party resubmitting a list/nominee shall resubmit the declaration under Regulation 18 [see page 327 above] to the effect that the political party has complied with the nomination rules and procedures of the party relating to the nomination of the names contained in the list/nominees. (2B) In the event that a political party fails to resubmit the list or a name on the party list after it has been rejected, the party shall not be considered in the ballot.'); (page 330 - '(1) Every political party shall establish an internal dispute resolution mechanism in relation to the party primaries. (1A) The dispute resolution mechanism of a party shall be independent of the party leadership and other party institutions. (1B) The dispute resolution mechanism of a party shall hear and determine all nomination disputes not later than ninety days before the date of general election. (2) The contravention of any of the provisions of the Election Offences Act (2016) or the breach of the Electoral Code of Conduct shall constitute electoral malpractice in relation to a party primary and party nomination of party lists.')
BPRESSELTXT: [IEBC - Candidates self-nominate]; [Party Statute, (Page 27 - '(1) The NDC shall have the powers and duties to nominate the Party's candidate for the election as the President and Deputy Prsident of the the Republic of Kenya') (Page 84 - '(1) The party shall conduct open, free, fair and transparent nominations in national elections through consensus, secret ballot, or through the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) or other democratic method acceptable to the members under the supervision of the National Elections Board and the County Elections Board. (2) Unless otherwise provided for in written agreement between the Party and any other party or coalition, the Party Presidential and Deputy Presidential candidates shall: 1. Be fully paid up members of the Party and shall provide copies of the following: A. Detailed Curriculum Vitae, B. National Identity Card, C. Voters Card or evidence of registration as a voter, D. Relevant academic and / or professional certificates, (3). Be nominated by the National Delegates Convention, in accordance with the Party Nomination Rules and Regulations, (4). Pay a non-refundable nomination fee as may be determined by the NEC from time to time, (5). Meet all the requirements for presidential elections under the Kenyan Constitution, this Constitution, the Electoral laws or any other law in force for the time being in the Republic of Kenya, (6). Sign an agreement with the Party binding them to abide by all duties and obligations required of them by the Party.') (Page 87 - '(1) Nothing in this Article shall preclude the Party from declining to present a candidate for any elective position in a general election or a by-election once the matter is upon the agenda, discussed and resolved by the National Executive Committee in consultation with the National Elections Board.') (Page 93 - '(1) The National Elections Board shall present to the National Executive Committee a list of all candidates contesting party positions or elections for presidential parliamentary or county level positions PROVIDED that the National Executive Committee may raise an objection with valid and very good reasons observing fairness and justice regarding the suitability of any candidate, and such objection shall be final.') (Page 97 - '(1)The National Elections Appeals Tribunal shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine disputes arising from party nominations and elections, (2) A member aggrieved by the presidential nominations shall lodge a complaint to the National Elections Appeals Tribunal which shall hear and determine such complaints, (3) The decision of National Elections Appeals Tribunal shall be final.') (Page 98 - '(1) Leaders of the Party shall bind themselves by signing the Party’s Code of Conduct.') (Page 104 - '(1) In nominating or electing persons to the party or public offices, the party shall at all times take into account the competence integrity and honesty of the nominees, social, cultural, geographical and religious diversity of Kenya, and the principles of youth and gender equity and disability, (2) The term of office for all elected leaders under this constitution shall be five (5) years commencing on the date of ratification of this constitution, (3) Nothing in this constitution, its rules, regulations or procedures shall preclude the NEC acting on its own or through the National Coordinating Committee from taking or making decision that it deems proper and fit in the interest of the Party.') (Page - '(1)    ]; [Nomination Rules & Regulations, Page 7 - '(1) "Voter" for the purposes of Presidential nominations means a Jubilee Party member who is a holder of a National Identity Card and is registered as a voter in that particular electoral area.') (Page 7 - '(1) the National Executive Committee shall have the final authority ... in determining the results of and actual election and or selection, and preparation and authentication of the list of Party nominees, to contest various elective and non-elective positions available to the people of Kenya (being members of the Party), (2) the NEC is the ultimate organ of the Party for determining the persons who succeed (by election or selection) in obtaining any nomination of the Party."] [Page 8 - '(1) A person is eligible for nomination as a Jubilee Party candidate if he/she - 1.1. is a citizen of Kenya, 1.2 is a registered Party member, 1.3 is qualified to stand for any elective or selective position in accordance with the laws of Kenya (page 35 - especially, Constitution of Kenya Article 137; The Elections Act Article 22, Article 23, Article 24, Article 26), 1.4 is a registered voter, 1.5 has signed the party Pledge, 1.6 his/her proposed nomination is seconded by a minimum number of registered Jubilee Party members as applies to the particular candidate position, 1.7 Seconders: - The minimum number of seconders is provided below: - 1.7.1 President - 2'] [Page 9 - '(1) A person is not qualified for nomination as a Jubilee Party candidate if the person - 1.1 owes allegiance to a foreign state, 1.2 is a State officer, or is acting in any State office (other than President, Deputy President, Governor, Deputy Governor, member of Parliament (the National Assembly or the Senate), member of a County Assembly), 1.3 is subject to a sentence of imprisonment exceeding six months imposed on him by such a court or substituted by competent authority for some other sentence imposed on him by such a court unless all possibility of appeal of review of the relevant sentence or decision has not been exhausted, 1.4 is of unsound mind, 1.5 is in violation of Chapter 6 of the Constitution of Kenya; or any other law on Integrity, 1.6 is bankrupt under the laws of Kenya, 1.7 has not paid the prescribed nomination fees as shall be determined by NEC, 1.8 has not produced all necessary identification documents required by the Party, 1.9 is by virtue of his own act of admission, under acknowledgement of allegiance, obedience or adherence to another political party.'] [Page 9 -10 - '(1) All persons seeking to contest Presidential Election on a Jubilee Party ticket (nomination) shall register to the Jubilee Party in respect of any election for which these Rules apply and shall - 1.1 Apply to the National Elections Board in the prescribed manner, 1.2 Submit with the application a duly completed and signed Code of Conduct to the party, 1.3 Fully and truthfully answer all questions posed by the Party, and supply all information that the Party may require in the application accurately and truthfully, 1.4 Submit his application to the National Election Board within the timeframe published by the National Elections Board, 1.5 Pay an application and nomination fee as shall be determined by the National Executive Committee.']; [Page 10 - ' (1) Upon receipt of the list of aspirants by the National Elections Board, such list shall be forwarded to the National Executive Committee.'] [Page 10 - '(1) The National Executive Committee shall in general be responsible for receiving and considering the various Provisional Party Nomination Lists from the National Elections Board, (2) In addition to and/or pursuant to the powers granted to it by the Party Constitution, the National Executive Committee has the power pursuant to these Rules to consider objections in respect of any candidate and on its motion to review the suitability of any person presented for Party nomination before or after the nomination - the National Executive Committee shall have the final decision on whether to accept or otherwise such a candidate.'] [Page 11 - The National Elections Board shall in general undertake the following functions - (1) 'conducting of the vetting of candidates for nomination and or election of the Party Candidates, (2) Overseeing and providing materials, directions and guidelines for the conduct of the vetting'] [Page 12 - '(1) The powers and functions of the National Elections Board may be delegated outsourced, or subcontracted to any entity which the National Executive Committee may deem necessary to achieve the objective of a free fair and credible nomination.'] [Page 15 - '(1) Nominations will constitute universal suffrage on a day designated by the National Elections Board and the County Elections Board. (2) The National Elections Board shall provide alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.' ] [Page 17 - '(1) Registration of party voters and revision of the register of voters under these regulations shall be carried out at all times, save that registration of party voters shall close one month or such other time as the NEC determine, but before the date on which parties are required to submit party membership lists to the IEBC, (2) Any person who has attained the age of eighteen years and is a holder of a national identity card or a Kenyan passport and whose name is not in the party membership and or register of voters of any other party may be registered as a voter under these rules upon application. (3) The National Elections Board shall announce the Nomination Day or days which shall be no more than thirty days before the day by which parties are required by law to have nominated candidates.'] [Page 18 - '(1) Any candidate, who on nomination day either by himself, his agents or supporters engages, permits or condones any acts of violence, whatsoever and howsoever may be disqualified. The Presiding Officer shall record and report on such a behavior within the Polling Centre and the decision made thereof.'] [Page 19 - (1) On nomination day(s), candidates duly cleared by the National Elections Board shall present themselves or by their designated agents be present before their respective Returning Officers with the Party Compliance Certificate.']; [Page 20 - '(1) Voting shall be done by Secret Ballot or as otherwise determined by the Elections Board, (2) All eligible voters shall identify themselves by holding their National Identity Cards before commencement of voting, (3) If only one person presents themselves for nomination by the day set aside for submission of applications for nomination as a candidate for a position under these rules, that candidate shall be declared duly nominated on the day designated by the National Elections Board for nominations.' ]; [Page 22 - '(1) In the event that there is a tie in the votes cast during the nomination process for any position the candidates, who received the greatest number of votes shall be subjected to a fresh election. Such fresh election must be held within seven days after the original election, (2) Any Candidates taking part in the elections and who is dissatisfied with the results shall be entitled to appeal to the National Elections Appeal Tribunal within 72 hours (3 Days) of the nomination results being announced by the Returning Officer, (3) These Rules shall prescribe the fees to be paid upon the lodging of an appeal, which fees will be calculated so as to cater wholly or partially for the reasonable sitting allowances for the members of the appellate Tribunal for sitting to hear and determine the appeal and secretarial services provided therefor, while taking in due consideration the economic realities of Kenya so as not to unduly discourage appeals.']; [Page 23 - (1) The appeal shall be lodged in the prescribed format (simply by writing to the appellate Tribunal and delivering the same to any member of the appellate Tribunal) and by paying the prescribed fee as per the rules and the schedule (2) Should the nomination or selection process be found and determined to be flawed and declared null and void by an Elections Appeals Tribunal upon an appeal within the time provided, the National Elections Board shall announce the dates and venue for fresh elections and, in the case of Presidential and Deputy Presidential nominations, conduct a repeat elections, and in any other case direct the County Elections Board for the affected County to conduct a repeat election, in the manner prescribed for conducting an election in these Rules. (2) Should the National Elections Appeals Tribunal hearing an appeal conclusively arrive at a decision, upon sufficient proof being adduced, that a candidate has secured his nomination through undue influence, corruption or other fraudulent means, it shall immediately make its decision known to the National Elections Board, which Board may proceed to set aside and nullify such nomination and have power to declare a winner or call for a re- election, (3) The decision of the National Elections Board shall be a subject of appeal to the National Appeals Tribunal whose decision shall be final.']; [Page 25 - '(1) The National Executive Committee may issue orders for the better carrying into the effect of these Rules'] [Page 28/36 - '(1) Nomination fees for aspirants - President: Not provided, (2) All Women, Youth and People with Disabilities (PWD) shall pay half the amounts for the respective position.']; [Page 28  - '(1) List of Requirements (+ certified copies of each) - a) Two passport size photographs, b) Original Identification Card or Passport used to register as a voter, c) Registered as a voter with IEBC (Confirm status at ORPP or IEBC website), d) HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS BOARD (HELB) CERTIFICATE, e) CERTIFICATE OF GOOD CONDUCT, f) ETHICS AND ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION (EACC) CERTIFICATE, g) KENYA REVENUE AUTHORITY (KRA) CERTIFICATE, h) CREDIT REFERENCE BUREAU (CRB) CERTIFICATE, i) ACADEMIC CERTIFICATES, j) PIN CERTIFICATE, k) JUBILEE MEMBERSHIP CARD, l) RESIGNATION LETTER FROM OTHER PARTIES, m) NOMINATION FEE RECEIPT, n) REGISTRATION FEE RECEIPT, o) CHECK PARTY MEMBERSHIP STATUS (RPP) www.orpp.or.ke']
C46PLSELTXT: [Party Statute, (Page 7 - '(1) You have the right as a member of the Jubilee Party to seek election for any party position, (2) The Jubilee Party is committed to ensuring democracy by enshrining it at all levels of the party. Internal elections will be conducted transparently in a manner that will be free and fair, with appropriate scrutiny from independent bodies. (3) Our Constitution outlines the rules and procedures for party elections which will be overseen by the Jubilee Party National Board of Elections and Independent Elections and Boundaries Commission (IEBC).') (Page 21 - '(1) Every member shall be entitled to seek and to vote in any elective position of and in the party.') (Page 27 -'(1) The National Delegates Convention shall have the powers and duties to elect from among the eligible members of the Party, the national officials of the party in accordance with this Constitution.') (Page 47 - '(1) The Party shall have the following national officials who shall be elected at the National Delegates Convention.') (Page 93 -'(1) The National Elections Board shall organise and supervise Party elections in open, transparent, free and fair elections and in compliance with the party nomination rules and the Electoral Laws in force. (2) National Elections Board shall present to the National Executive Committee a list of all candidates contesting party positions, PROVIDED that the National Executive Committee may raise an objection with valid and very good reasons observing fairness and justice regarding the suitability of any candidate, and such objection shall be final.') (Page 97 - '(1)  The National Elections Appeals Tribunal shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine disputes arising from party nominations and elections. (2) Any member aggrieved in respect of all other party elections shall lodge a complaint with the National Elections Appeals Tribunal, (3) The decision of National Elections Appeals Tribunal shall be final.') (Page 98 - '(1) Leaders of the Party shall bind themselves by signing the Party’s Code of Conduct.') (Page 104 - '(1) In  electing persons to the party or public offices, the party shall at all times take into account the competence integrity and honesty of the nominees, social, cultural, geographical and religious diversity of Kenya, and the principles of youth and gender equity and disability. (2) In constituting party organs, no one gender shall comprise more than two thirds (2/3) of the membership. (3) The term of office for all elected leaders under this constitution shall be five (5) years commencing on the date of ratification of this constitution. (4) All holders of offices under this constitution shall comply with the requirement of Chapter Six of the Constitution of Kenya, the Public Officer’s Ethics Act, The Leadership and Integrity Act and all other relevant provisions of the law governing public leadership. (5) Nothing in this constitution, its rules, regulations or procedures shall preclude the NEC acting on its own or through the National Coordinating Committee from taking or making decision that it deems proper and fit in the interest of the Party.') (Page 108 - DURING THE TRANSITION (see C24PLRULE) - '(1) The President of the Republic of Kenya shall be the Party Leader and the Deputy President shall be the Deputy Party Leader. (2) The Party Leader and the Deputy Party Leader shall nominate interim National Officials of the party having regard to the officials and strengths of the parties being dissolved, regional, gender, youth, disability and other diversities, and the best interests of the merged party. (3) The National Executive Committee shall appoint a committee which shall facilitate nomination of interim officials of the party at county, Constituency, ward and polling stations. (4) All interim party officials shall serve for a term not exceeding three (3) years from the date of appointment unless he/she is elected as provided under this constitution.')]

TITLE: Political Party Database
A4RECPARTYTXT: The Political Parties Act (2018) specifies that for a party to be registered it must provide a list giving the names, addresses and signatures of not less than one hundred members of the party and resident in each of the districts of Malawi
A5RECPPGTXT: For a party to be registered, it must: have not less that 100 people in each of the country's districts, provide two copies of the constitution. rules and manifesto of the party
A79CONWOMTXT: 9 duly accredited delegates from the women committee
A81CONDELTXT: All members of the National Governing Council
A91EXCWOMTXT: The DPP's Constitution states that the Women Directorate in the party shall be represented in the National governing Council by  the National Director of Women, First Deputy Director for Women and the Second Deputy Director for Women
A110EXPELTXT: Not Provided
B2BALLOTTXT: If a candidate is to stand for, or is sponsored by a political party, this fact should be specified together with the name of the political party and the name of the candidate alongside a distinctive symbol which the candidate wishes to appear on the ballot paper in conjuction with him. Further, the nomination paper shall be countersigned by a person who is an office bearer of the political party concerned and who has athority to certify that the candidate is to stand for that political party.
B35PRESBALLOTTXT: The nomination of a candidate for election to the office of President shall be made by at least ten registered voters in each district each of whom shall sign a nomination paper in the prescribed form. In addition, if the candidate is to stand for or to be sponsored by a political party, specify that fact, together with the name of the political party, the name of the candidate and an abbreviation of the name of the candidate and the distinctive symbol and other particulars approved by the Commission which the candidate wishes to appear on the ballot paper in conjunction with him. The nomination should be accompanied by evidence or a statutory declaration by the candidate made before a magistrate or a commissioner for oaths, that the candidate is a citizen of Malawi and has attained the minimum age required by the Constitution for the election to the office of President.
BPRESSELTXT: The party doesn’t have any other legislations apart from its constitution
C46PLSELTXT: The National Political Conference shall consist of all members of the National Governing Council, Regional Committee members, District Committee members, all Members of Parliament belonging to the party and 9 duly elected delegates from the Main, Women, and Youth committees. This conference shall have the responsibility of electing office holders to various positions
